header.aside: If you love questbars, you'll die for this questbarwich which packs 36 grams of protein! That's more than a protein shake, my Choppers.

section.p: I discovered Questnutrition's protein bars a couple of years ago when I was looking for gluten- and soy-free protein bars on amazon. (I had recently been diagnosed with a host of food intolerances and was in a panic to find something I could still eat.) Unfortunately, the first generation of quest bars tasted like cardboard, and were so difficult to chew that they would give me a jaw-ache. Frustrated, I decided they had been a waste of money. A few years later however, pictures of quest bars kept popping up on my Instagram feed on Instagram, and I wondered why they were so trendy all of a sudden. I decided to try out their new flavours, and oh Lila, am I glad I did!

tr.td: Fage 0% Total Fat-free Greek Yoghurt (85g) or
vanilla whey protein powder (I used Cellucor Whipped Vanilla)
very dark chocolate, such as Lindt 90%

section.p: I discovered through Instagram that the trick with questbars is to microwave them first. (Whoever first thought of this must be both some bizarre genius.) Just 10 seconds in the microwave makes a tremendous difference, both in taste and chewability, thereby significantly increasing their edibility. It also makes the bar easier to mould into shapes for baking - but be warned! They settle and harden very quickly.

tr.td: Mix the yoghurt, berries and coconut in a bowl.
Put the yoghurt mixture in the freezer to make sandwich ice cream filling whilst preparing the questbar.
Heat the quest bar in the microwave.
Cut in half and roll into 2 flat round cookies.
Take frozen yoghurt mixture out of the freezer and layer between the quest bars cookies to make a sandwich.
Melt dark chocolate in microwave (careful not to let it burn).
Devour immediately, before the questbar cookies harden.

section.p: As you can see, this is a very nutrient- and protein- dense treat. To make it lighter, simply halve the recipe, or skip the protein powder altogether.

A little note on the macro nutrients: although the macros for the total amount of carbohydrates looks high, questbars are made up of insoluble prebiotic plant fibres called Isomalto-Oligosaccharides, therefore the amount of net carbohydrates is significantly lower. That's why I can safely call this recipe low-carb and high-protein.
